abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is unsatisfactory; sustainability is highly
            unlikely; institutional development impact is modest; Bank
            performance is unsatisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            unsatisfactory.   There were 4 significant lessons learned
            from this project: 1. Contributions from other donors should
            not be reflected in the project costing and activities
            schedule unless firm commitments have been obtained. In the
            absence of this, explicit arrangements should be included in
            the Credit financing and covenants to ensure that these
            activities can be continued if the donor financing does not
            materialize. If the donor funds are made available, the
            concomitant Credit funds can either be cancelled or
            reallocated to other activities. 2. Where Borrower
            commitment to various project activities appears uneven,
            strategies should be developed to ensure that the
            implementing activities seen as lower priority by the
            Borrower is not adversely affected if problems occur in
            other activities considered higher priority. Further, teams
            should carefully consider the extent to which social sector
            projects which aim to support substantial sectoral
            restructuring should also include large infrastructure
            investments. 3. Monitoring and evaluation indicators should
            include key benchmarks and decision points, especially where
            activities require substantial implementation time. The time
            schedules for lengthy implementation activities should be
            carefully constructed, allowing an appropriate length of
            time for each step of the process, and also reflecting the
            experience and expertise of the implementation agency. 4.
            Small punctuated technical assistance interventions (such as
            those introduced during the mid-term review) achieve little,
            as they fail to substantially engage counterparts, do not
            build up a longer-term relationship of mutual trust, and do
            not result in the TA activity becoming an integral part of
            the implementing agency's work program. A more
            comprehensive, coherent and longer-term technical assistance
            program is usually necessary.
